div1.p: Griffitts writes that he would like to be assigned to North Carolina.

div1.head: Letter from T.H.D. Griffitts to Henry Rose Carter, January 15, 1923
div1.opener:
N. M. C.
I. W.
Mobile, Ala.
1-15-23,
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
Your letter of 8th was here when I returned
from a two day trip to Montgomery.

I am greatly interested in your letter to Dr. F.,
and thank you very much for the details nextconcerning
expansions N. C. projects. I don't know what Dr. F.
will do about it. All I can say on this point is,
I hope his action will be based upon your advise,
After getting your letter, I wrote him that should
he consider changing me to that area it would
in no way inconvenience me now, (I thought,
perhaps, he might hesitate to change my orders
if he thought I have my family with me, etc-
which I have not).

I believe that from the standpoint of scien-
tific studies, the conditions under which and
on which one would work in that area
would be best for continuous investigations.
I can see that work in Alabama will be
divided into (1) studies in conditions of impounded
waters and (2) assisting and advising on preventive
measures based on what we already know
or think of necessary to limit or prevent pond
malaria. I fear that (2) will take up so
much time in Alabama as to interrupt con-
tinuous studies, which we know, from
our standpoint, are the more important. Since the

since the promulgation of the I. W. regulations, Mr.
Hazlehurst says that ponds are beginning to show
up, and they will probably be “rushed with orders”
I think that we should have another engineer,
aside from Le Prince, familiar with im-
pounded waters. An engineer (trained) should
be the better man for services with S. B. of H.
and in advising on control of ponds. Since
you are on “Waiting Orders”-(unfortunate for Service)
Le Prince, a good second, and I, a poor third
are the only ones who could give the training.
I should certainly suggest this, if I were ever
asked for suggestions as to policy. I think
Fisher would be our best man.

You may recall that I wrote you soon after
the war- 1919- that I was sorry we couldn't
stick more closely to investigations instead of
getting so much into “cooperative control.” I
don't dislike construction (I think you would
say that my work just finished is one of, if
not the best anywhere), but I feel that it
would be my duty to do it, if I were a
local health officer.

I hope your excellent advice will be
followed, and pray that your hopes and desires
that these studies be carried on to a logical con-
clusion as to “Relation of Impounded Waters to the
Incidence of Malaria” and the “determination of the
3
methods of minimizing such incidence. My ability
to help reach these results my opportunity through
orders and personal limitations. The latter
only I can strive to overcome - and
I would do it for your satisfaction, to
say nothing of other values.
Kindest regards to Miss Laura & your good self.
